critique: This document establishes a board to investigate a labor dispute between two railroad companies and their employees in Vermont. It aims to prevent interruption of interstate commerce by maintaining the status quo for 30 days while the board investigates and reports its findings. The order is based on the authority vested in the president by section 10 of the Railway Labor Act. There is no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, or social inclusion. The executive power is somewhat expanded as the president is creating a board and intervening in a labor dispute. Federalism is neutral as it addresses interstate commerce, which is a federal concern. National security vs. civil liberties is balanced as it aims to prevent disruption of essential transportation services while maintaining existing labor conditions. Economic regulation leans towards intervention as the government is stepping in to resolve a labor dispute and prevent economic disruption.
